entries.meaning: (obsolete) A red-orange dye obtained from brazil wood. [14thâ€“17th c.]
examples: A small Quantity of Saffron will Tinct more then a very great Quantity of Brasil.

entries.meaning: The hard, brown wood of a tree of the tribe Caesalpinieae; originally the sappan, Biancaea sappan, of the East Indies, and later the brazilwood, Paubrasilia echinata. [from 15th c.]
examples: The Prouince Brasilia tooke his name of the woode called Brasill.
I picked up a handful of brazils from the bowl.

entries.meaning: A seam of coal containing iron pyrites
